newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai PM says Burma's leader may resign-paper.
newsitem.headline: Thai PM says Burma's leader may resign-paper.

text.p: A Thai newspaper on Saturday quoted the country's Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh as saying his Burmese counterpart General Than Shwe was considering giving up his top position.

Chavalit said he believed Than Shwe -- who is also chairman of Burma's ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) -- did not want to stay on in the position and was thinking of retiring, according to the report in The Nation newspaper.
Chavalit, who is also defence minister, is known to have close ties to SLORC leaders.
Burmese government officials were not immediately avaiable for comment on the report.
But commentaries in the official media said the SLORC was strong and united.
"The SLORC is one with the people though it is a military government," the commentary said.
"(SLORC leaders) are united, have mutual love and discipline with their hands firmly linked, and respect and uphold their responsibilities for the nation and people," it said.
The Thai prime minister was quoted as saying Than Shwe could not yet quit due to problems with a reshuffle in the lower-level Burmese military hierarchy.
"He (Than Shwe) is thinking of retiring, but there are some hitches at the lower level which require the further rearrangement of officials," Chavalit said.

"General Than Shwe does not want to stay on in his position, which is somewhat like the case of General Saw Maung. These people are not bad people," he said on Friday during a visit to Kanchanaburi near Thailand's western border with Burma.
General Saw Maung headed the SLORC when it took power in September 1988 after crushing pro-democracy protests in which thousands were killed or imprisoned. But he quit as SLORC's top general in 1992.
In late 1988, Chavalit visited Burma to meet the country's top generals despite an internationally-imposed isolation of the country when the military seized power.
The Thai premier plans to visit Burma in the near future, the Nation said without giving further details.

Some analysts and diplomats have speculated that there might be a split within the secretive SLORC between hardliners and moderates which could lead to a restructuring of Burma's leadership in the future.
Than Shwe is considered a moderate leader within the SLORC, diplomats said.
Burmese military sources have denied rumours of any split.
Burma has recently been hit by religious unrest and a bomb attack at the home of the SLORC's hardline Secretary Two, General Tin Oo, which killed his daughter.
The country has also been fraught with image problems as it continues to curb the pro-democracy movement led by opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi.
